pr_title: XRDDEV-882/883 APIs for adding and deleting configured timestamping services

timeline.message:
XRDDEV-910 API for listing configured timestamping services

- Implement API for listing configured timestamping services.
- Update OpenAPI description.
- Add unit tests.
- Enable eager loading of configured timestamping services in serverconf DAO.
- Implement reverse ordering of returned timestamping services so that they're in the order used by proxy.

XRDDEV-910 Fix proxy-ui-api incorrect target folder in Ansible script

- Change proxy-ui-api target folder from /usr/share/xroad/jlib/webapps to /usr/share/xroad/jlib.

XRDDEV-910 Update unit tests

- Add new test that verifies that timestamping services are returned in reverse order.

XRDDEV-910 Refactor loading of configured timestamping services

- Revert changes in server conf DAO.
- Use Hibernate.initialize to load timestamping service objects.
- Remove reverse ordering of returned timestamping services.

XRDDEV-883 API for deleting configured timestamping services

- Implement API for deleting configured timestamping services.
- Update OpenAPI description.
- Add unit tests.
XRDDEV-910 Refactor API and service layers
XRDDEV-883 Merge changes from branch XRDDEV-910

XRDDEV-882 API for adding new configured timestamping services

- Implement API for adding new configured timestamping services.
- Add unit tests.

timeline.bodyText:
Instead of multi-type-converters with instanceof conditional it would probably be more consistent with the existing converters to have separate convert(Iterable<String> list) and convert(<TspType> list) methods.
I have another suggestion about removing convert(Iterable) altogether elsewhere, though.
timeline.author: jansu76

replies.bodyText:
Having methods convert(Iterable<String> list) and convert(Iterable<TspType> list) is not possible, because they still have the same erasure.
One alternative would be name them differently, e.g., convertString(Iterable<String> list) and convertTspType(Iterable<TspType> list).
replies.author: petkivim

replies.bodyText: Ah, I did not realize that. Yeah, different names could be one option. I am still thinking we could avoid that though - more at #372 (comment).
replies.author: jansu76

timeline.bodyText: What do you think about changing this to public Collection<TspType> getApprovedTimestampingServices() with TspType.id = null (and documenting that in the javadoc)? That would make it easier for the callers to handle both types of timestamping services with same constructs, especially it would enable bit of simplification for TimestampingServiceConverter and remove globalConfFacade calls from it. It would make converter layer more thin and dumb and I think unless there's some trouble related to that, we should try to do that to focus business logic inside the service layer. There's some exceptions to this (member name lookups, security server owner lookups) but ideally they should be minimized.
timeline.author: jansu76

replies.bodyText: I ended up removing the whole TimestampingServiceService class since it was not really needed after the API changes.
replies.author: petkivim

replies.bodyText:
All right. The question about converter / service roles remains still though.
What do you think about something like this: e750d03 ?
I think TimestampingServiceConverter and GlobalConfService are a bit more close to what their roles "usually" are, and converter is thinner and dumber.
Disclaimer: I did not live test this. Automatic tests pass though.
replies.author: jansu76

replies.bodyText:
I think that your solution looks good. Now the service layer returns TspType objects for both approved and configured  timestamping services which makes the implementation more consistent and simplifies the converter.
I merged the changes, tested the API manually, and everything works as expected.
replies.author: petkivim

timeline.bodyText:
We have used convention where response has Location header which points to created entity. There is a helper to make this convenient, 
  
    
      X-Road/src/proxy-ui-api/src/main/java/org/niis/xroad/restapi/openapi/ClientsApiController.java
    
    
         Line 308
      in
      c5d7658
    
    
    
    

        
          
           return createCreatedResponse("/api/local-groups/{id}", createdGroup, localGroupType.getId()); 
        
    
  


We do not have a single-item-getter for timestamping services, so I wonder which would be better, a) point to all-items-getter /token-certificates or b) not include Location header at all?
timeline.author: jansu76

replies.bodyText: I ended up leaving this as-is - not including Location header since we do not have an endpoint for a single timestamping entity.
replies.author: petkivim

replies.bodyText: With a fresh mind this (b) is indeed the better option since it is better to not provide wrong Location header if we cannot provide a correct one.  Discussed same thing with @TJaakkola today, about Endpoint delete, since we don't have a single item getter for that either.
replies.author: jansu76
